snippet: The automakers’ efforts reflect the importance of finding a way to harvest used batteries because batteries are expensive to produce and hard to recycle or dispose of properly, said Karl Brauer of Kelley Blue Book.
abstract: Nissan and General Motors announce separate plans to repurpose electric car batteries that remain potent even after they have lost capacity necessary to power vehicles; Nissan announces partnership with Green Charge Networks to create stationary storage systems and General Motors will use batteries to power testing campus in Milford, Mich.
lead_paragraph: The automakers’ efforts reflect the importance of finding a way to harvest used batteries because batteries are expensive to produce and hard to recycle or dispose of properly, said Karl Brauer of Kelley Blue Book.

headline.main: G.M. and Nissan Reusing Old Electric Car Batteries
headline.print_headline: G.M. and Nissan Reusing Old Electric Car Batteries
